conclusion: Two objects, A and B, start from the same place and move in the same direction; need to find when they are farthest apart.
Graph is velocity vs. time with points t1, t2, t3, t4; velocities change over time.
Object A's velocity starts high and decreases; Object B's velocity increases then decreases.
Area under velocity-time graph gives displacement.
Distance between objects at time t is |S_A(t) - S_B(t)|.
Need to find time when distance |S_A(t) - S_B(t)| is maximized.
At t=0, both start from the same point, so distance is 0.
Between t=0 and t1, Object A moves ahead of Object B.
At t1, Object A's velocity is still higher than Object B's.
Between t1 and t2, Object A's velocity decreases, Object B's increases.
At t2, Object A's velocity is still higher than Object B's.
Between t2 and t3, Object A's velocity decreases to zero, Object B's increases.
At t3, Object B's velocity is higher than Object A's.
After t3, Object A's velocity might become negative, Object B's decreases.
From t=0 to t2, Object A moves ahead, increasing distance.
After t2, Object B starts catching up, decreasing distance.
Maximum distance should be around t2.
Consider displacements: S_A(t) and S_B(t) as integrals of velocities.
Distance is maximized when rate of change of distance is zero.
Distance increases as long as Object A is faster; decreases when Object B is faster.
At t2, Object A has maximum lead over Object B.
After t2, Object B reduces the distance.
Correct answer is B. t2.
